channel.title: Gui theme
channel.description:
im writing a gui program in swing
any1 know how to set the theme so looks like mopars window theme? i believe it may be default but mines not set also, i wanna d this in my rs client know which.java to put in?

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Well when retrieving data on the http protocol, your client will download the data from the beginning to the end of the file…therefore, all you need is the byte length of the file to continue the download. You don’t need to store any data in a text file.

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:60, topic:5797”]What data do you need to save? Just flush the output stream occasionally to make sure you don’t have too much data in the buffer if the download stops, and when you want to resume a download, just get the byte count of the partially downloaded file and use that as the Range property value…[/quote]Nah, I mean like when I’m going to resume the downloads, what data is going to be needed to resume the downloads that were in progress.

Like in Limewire; when you open up the client, it has the few downloads that weren’t completely done at the bottom connecting, ect. Does it just save a text file of the names or the files, amount downloaded, ect?

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

What data do you need to save? Just flush the output stream occasionally to make sure you don’t have too much data in the buffer if the download stops, and when you want to resume a download, just get the byte count of the partially downloaded file and use that as the Range property value…

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

What method are you using to download the file in the first place?

If you use a URL connection (like new URL(“http://mysite.com/page.php”).openConnection()), you can set certain http header properties - the one you want is Range. Here’s a definition of the Range header field from W3: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.35

If you need some help with that code, I’ll give you a hand with it, but I’ll let you have a stab at it yourself first this time

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Hah, I really did need to figure out what that last bit did. When I put it in, and cleaned up the stuff that was originally there, the JWindow would keep turning up white, so I knew I messed up somewhere. So then after butchering it, like, three times I found the problem. I forgot about two lines of code, so yeah. That’d be a problem.

What do you think I could do to resume downloads when the client is back up? After closing save all the current downloads information to a txt: the url, stuff downloaded so far… and then get that info a start writing again? I’m not to sure how to do that part. You’re probably don’t know how it works now, the downloading part. Want me to walk you through?

Read full topic

@BobDole81 wrote:

		JLabel splashLabel = new JLabel(new ImageIcon("Images/Splash" + rand + ".jpg"));
		JLabel loadingText = new JLabel("Loading...");
		loadingText.setHorizontalAlignment(JLabel.CENTER);
		loadingText.setBackground(new Color(0,0,0,0));
		loadingText.setBounds((x - 100) / 2, 50, 100, 20);
		splashPage.add(loadingText, BorderLayout.CENTER);
		splashPage.add(splashLabel, BorderLayout.CENTER);

Exception in thread “main” java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: getGraphics(
) not valid for images created with createImage(producer)

“Graphics splashGraphics = splashImage.getGraphics();”

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Well, since you’re using an image anyway, how about drawing your string right onto the Image?

Image splashImage = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("Images/Splash" + rand + ".jpg");
Graphics splashGraphics = splashImage.getGraphics();
splashGraphics .drawString("Loading" + msg, 50, 50);

Then, of course, use splashImage as your parameter for the ImageIcon constructor. Again, I didn’t test it and I’ve never done something like that, so I hope it works

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

splashFrame.setBounds((screenSize.width - x) / 2, (screenSize.height - y) / 2, x, y);

You don’t need the setSize call because setBounds specifies it for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Gui theme
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[code]import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.;
import java.util.Random;

class Splash extends JComponent {
String msg = “”;
int x, y;
JWindow splashFrame;

public Splash() {
	splashFrame = new JWindow();
	JPanel splashPage = new JPanel(new BorderLayout());
	splashPage.setBackground(Color.BLACK);

	int rand = new Random().nextInt(40);
	if (rand > 20) {
		x = 360;
		y = 320;
		rand = 1;
	} else {
		x = 380;
		y = 320;
		rand = 0;
	}

	Dimension screenSize = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize();
	//splashFrame.setBounds((screenSize.width - splashFrame.getWidth()) / 2,
	//		(screenSize.height - splashFrame.getHeight()) / 2, splashFrame.getWidth(),
	//			splashFrame.getHeight());

	splashFrame.setBounds(screenSize.width / 2, 100, screenSize.height / 2, 100);

	splashFrame.setSize(x, y);

	JLabel splashLabel = new JLabel(new ImageIcon("Images/Splash" + rand + ".jpg"));
	splashPage.add(splashLabel, BorderLayout.CENTER);
	splashFrame.add(splashPage);
	splashFrame.setVisible(true);

	try {
		for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
			if (i == 4)
				msg = "";
			repaint();
			msg += ".";
			Thread.sleep(800L);
			System.out.println(i);
		}
	} catch (Exception e) {}
}


public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
	g.drawString("Loading" + msg, 50, 50);

}
}
[/code]
The drawString method doesn’t work. Those coords definately aren’t correct either. I was just trying to get it to work.

And, in my main constructor (Which is called in my main() method), calls a reference to the splash class and at the end of the main constructor, it is told to hide.

Read full topic
